segment.target: Comparison filter types

segment.source: Only use linear filtering if the device can afford the performance penalty.
segment.target: Only use linear filtering if the device can afford the performance penalty.

segment.source: Generally, Direct3D feature level 9\_1 devices don't have enough power to spare for linear filtering on shadows.
segment.target: Generally, Direct3D feature level 9\_1 devices don't have enough power to spare for linear filtering on shadows.

segment.source: Use point filtering instead on these devices.
segment.target: Use point filtering instead on these devices.

segment.source: When you use linear filtering, adjust the pixel shader so that it blends the shadow edges.
segment.target: When you use linear filtering, adjust the pixel shader so that it blends the shadow edges.

segment.source: Shadow buffer size
segment.target: Shadow buffer size

segment.source: Larger shadow maps won't look as blocky but they take up more space in graphics memory.
segment.target: Larger shadow maps won't look as blocky but they take up more space in graphics memory.

segment.source: Experiment with different shadow map sizes in your game and observe the results in different types of devices and different display sizes.
segment.target: Experiment with different shadow map sizes in your game and observe the results in different types of devices and different display sizes.

segment.source: Consider an optimization like cascaded shadow maps to get better results with less graphics memory.
segment.target: Consider an optimization like cascaded shadow maps to get better results with less graphics memory.

segment.source: Shadow buffer depth
segment.target: Shadow buffer depth

segment.source: Greater precision in the shadow buffer will give more accurate depth test results, which helps avoid issues like z-buffer fighting.
segment.target: Greater precision in the shadow buffer will give more accurate depth test results, which helps avoid issues like z-buffer fighting.

segment.source: But like larger shadow maps, greater precision takes up more memory.
segment.target: But like larger shadow maps, greater precision takes up more memory.

segment.source: Experiment with different depth precision types in your game - DXGI\_FORMAT\_R24G8\_TYPELESS versus DXGI\_FORMAT\_R16\_TYPELESS - and observe the speed and quality on different feature levels.
segment.target: Experiment with different depth precision types in your game - DXGI\_FORMAT\_R24G8\_TYPELESS versus DXGI\_FORMAT\_R16\_TYPELESS - and observe the speed and quality on different feature levels.

segment.source: Optimizing precompiled shaders
segment.target: Optimizing precompiled shaders

segment.source: Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps can use dynamic shader compilation, but it's faster to use dynamic shader linking.
segment.target: Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps can use dynamic shader compilation, but it's faster to use dynamic shader linking.

segment.source: You can also use compiler directives and blocks to create different versions of shaders.
segment.target: You can also use compiler directives and blocks to create different versions of shaders.

segment.source: This is done by opening the Visual Studio project file in a text editor and adding multiple entries for the HLSL (each with the appropriate preprocessor definitions).
segment.target: This is done by opening the Visual Studio project file in a text editor and adding multiple entries for the HLSL (each with the appropriate preprocessor definitions).

segment.source: Note that this necessitates different filenames; in this case, Visual Studio appends \_point and \_linear to the different versions of the shader.
